subClasses.name: Parallel Negative Limiter with Negative Bias Behavior
Parallel Negative Limiter with Positive Bias Behavior
Parallel Positive Limiter with Bias Behavior
Parallel Positive Limiter with Negative Bias Behavior
Parallel Positive Limiter with Positive Bias Behavior
Series Negative Limiter with Negative Bias Behavior
Series Negative Limiter with Positive Bias Behavior
Series Positive Limiter with Negative Bias Behavior
Series Positive Limiter with Positive Bias Behavior
Full Wave Rectifier with Zener Behavior
CE Transistor Voltage Divider Bias Behavior
Dragoon Interactions
subClasses.template: Used to track skill with Dragoon.

subClasses.name: Linear
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a constant value.
subClasses.example: The perimeter of an area increases by 5 hectares every year. What is the perimeter after 4 years?

subClasses.name: Exponential
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a certain rate.
subClasses.example: A certain element has a half-life of 2 years. If there is 60 pounds of the material, how much time will it take until there is less than one pound?

subClasses.name: Goal-seeking
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a rate which is proportional to difference between two quantities out of which atleast one of them is not a source or destination.
subClasses.example: The velocity of a pendulum (point mass m and mass-less thread length l) is inversely proporitonal by a factor 'k', to the difference of distance of its current position and the equilibrium position. If it is taken to a height h and left then find the time it takes to come back to its original position?

subClasses.name: Equilibrating
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a rate which is proportional to difference between the source and the destination quantities.
subClasses.example: Water flows through a porus membrane by factor of -0.3 times the difference of density of salt at both the places. How much time will it take to reach the equilibrium condition?

subClasses.name: Accelerating
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a rate which increases or decreases by a constant amount every time.
subClasses.example: A car starts 2m/sec and has an accelerationg which increases by 0.5m/sec^2 starting from 0 at time = 0 sec. What will be the speed of the vehicle after 10 seconeds?

subClasses.name: Epidemic
subClasses.template: An amount increases/decays at a rate, which is the product of the number of meetings times the probability that a meeting will have a both a source and a destination object in it.

subClasses.name: Ohm's Law: Voltage
subClasses.template: Current flowing through a a load is directly proportional to voltage across it and inversely proportional to the resistance of the load.
subClasses.example: Find the current running through a load when voltage difference provided by the source is 5V and resistance of the load is 1000 ohms.

subClasses.name: Kirchoff's Current Law
subClasses.template: At a junction in the circuit the sum of all the currents is zero, where current flowing into the node are taken as negative and flowing away are taken as positive.
subClasses.example: There is a 10 mA current flowing into node A. The junction divides into two paths. If current flowing through one of them is 2mA, then how much current is flowing in the other path?

subClasses.name: Kirchoff's Voltage Law
subClasses.template: Voltage change in a complete closed loop is 0.
subClasses.example: Find the current flowing through two loads in parallel when they are connected to a source of 10V?

subClasses.name: Superposition
subClasses.template: Current in a circuit with more than one independent sources is given by the sum of current from individual sources.
subClasses.example: There are two independent sources of 5V and 10V in parallel to a load of 1000 ohms. Find the current flowing through it.

subClasses.name: Resistance of two resistors in Series
Resistance of two resistors in Parallel
Smoothing capacitor for a full wave rectifier
Motion - Simple DRT
subClasses.template: A vehicle travels a certain distance in a certain amount of time at a certain speed.
subClasses.example: Bill Less drove from Boston to Cleveland, a distance of 624 miles, in the time of 12 hours. Find his rate of driving.

subClasses.name: Motion - Overtake
subClasses.template: One vehicle starts and is followed later by a second vehicle that travels over the same route at a faster rate.
subClasses.example: A train leaves a station and travels east at 72 km/h. Three hours later a second train leaves on a parallel track and travels east at 120 km/h. How long will it take to overtake the first train?

subClasses.name: Motion - Opposite direction
subClasses.template: Two vehicles leave the same point traveling in opposite directions.
subClasses.example: Two trains leave the same station at the same time. They travel in opposite directions. One train travels 64 km/h and the other 104 km/h. In how many hours will they be 1008 km apart?

subClasses.name: Motion - Round trip
subClasses.template: = A traveler (or vehicle) travels from point A to point B and returns.
subClasses.example: George rode out of town on the bus at an average speed of 20 miles per hour and walked back at an average speed of 3 miles per hour. How far did he go if the entire trip took six hours?

subClasses.name: Motion - Closure 1
subClasses.template: Two vehicles start at different points traveling towards one another.
subClasses.example: Two cyclists start at the same time from towns 36 miles apart. The cyclists move toward each other; one travels at 4 mph and the other at 8 mph. How long will it take for them to meet?

subClasses.name: Motion - Speed change 1
subClasses.template: A vehicle travels at a certain rate for the first leg of a trip and then changes to another rate for the remainder of the trip.
subClasses.example: G. Otrotrot jogs and walks to school each day. He averages 4 km/h walking and 8 km/h jogging. The distance from home to school is 6 km and he makes the trip in I hour. How far does he jog in a trip?

subClasses.name: Current - Total time 1
subClasses.template: A boat travels a certain distance with the current and a certain distance against the current in a total time.
subClasses.example: The current in a stream moves at a speed of 4 km/h. A boat travels 4 km upstream and 12 km downstream in a total time of 2 hours. What is the speed of the boat in still water?

subClasses.name: Current - Round trip 1
subClasses.template: A boat travels a certain distance with the current and a certain distance against the current in a total time.
subClasses.example: The current in a stream moves at a speed of 4 km/h. A boat travels 4 km upstream and 12 km downstream in a total time of 2 hours. What is the speed of the boat in still water?

subClasses.name: Current - Round trip 2
subClasses.template: A boat travels with the current in a certain time and returns in a certain time against the current.
subClasses.example: Fly High Airlines flies from Po dunk to Swampville in 5 hours with a tailwind. The return trip, against the same wind, takes 6 hours. Podunk is about 5550 km from Swampville. Find the speed of the plane and the velocity of the wind.

subClasses.name: Cost Unit Total
subClasses.template: A certain unit cost for a certain number of units yields a total cost.
subClasses.example: Jean worked 5 hours. She earned a total of $1 S. How much does she earn each hour?

subClasses.name: Fixed plus units
subClasses.template: Total cost (or wage) is based on a flat cost plus a certain unit cost applied to a certain number of units.
subClasses.example: Sixteen balls of yarn can be bought from a mail order house for 29(: each plus $2.72 for postage. What does the total order cost?

subClasses.name: Total number given
subClasses.template: A certain number of coins, consisting of two different types of coins, totals a certain total amount.
subClasses.example: A collection of 25 dimes and quarters amounts to $5.05. How many of each kind of coin are there?

subClasses.name: Relative number given
subClasses.template: In a collection of two types of coins, the number of one type is related to the number of the other type and the collection is worth a certain total amount.
subClasses.example: Ken's coin collections contains·7 more dimes than nickels. In all, the collection amounts to $3.25. How many of each coin does he have?

subClasses.name: Simple interest and time
subClasses.template: A certain interest rate applied simply to a certain principal for a certain amount of time yields a certain amount of interest.
subClasses.example: Sheila borrowed $2700 from the bank at 9% interest. She paid $499.50 in interest. How long did she keep the loan?

subClasses.name: Compound time
subClasses.template: A certain interest rate applied compounded to a certain principal for a certain amount of time yields a certain amount of interest.
subClasses.example: Suppose $750 is invested at 5% compounded annually. What amount will be on the account at the end of two years?

subClasses.name: Interest - Two absolute amounts
subClasses.template: A certain amount of money is split into two parts with one part invested at one rate and the other part invested at another interest rate.
subClasses.example: Part of $2000 is invested at 7.5% annual interest. The rest is invested at 6%. Last year's interest was $136.50. How much money was invested at each rate?

subClasses.name: Interest - Two relative amounts
subClasses.template: A certain amount of money is invested at one rate and another amount is invested at another rate.
subClasses.example: Delaine Jones invested a certain amount of money at 6% annual interest and $2000 more than that amount at 8% annual interest. Last year she received $580 in interest. How much did she invest at each rate?

subClasses.name: Dry - Two absolute amounts
subClasses.template: Some amount of one item with a certain unit cost is mixed with some amount of another item with a certain unit cost to yield a total amount with a certain unit cost; individual
subClasses.example: Jean worked 5 hours. She earned a total of $1 S. How much does she earn each hour?

subClasses.name: Dry - Two relative amounts
subClasses.template: Some amount of one item with a certain unit cost is mixed with some amount of another item with a certain unit cost to yield a total amount with a certain total cost, relative amounts are known.
subClasses.example: Pedro wants to mix candy selling at $2.20 per kg with another selling at $2040 per kg. He wants to make an $11.60 gift box. The number of kg at $2.20 per kg is 1 less than the number of kg at $2.40 per kg. Find the number of kg of each.

subClasses.name: Wet - Add to given
subClasses.template: Given a certain amount of one solution, some amount of another solution is added to yield a total amount of a new solution.
subClasses.example: A chemist has 3:1 of a 5% acid solution. How many liters of a 20% solution must be added to make a mixture which is 10% acid?

subClasses.name: Wet - Two absolute amounts
subClasses.template: Some amount of one solution is mixed with some amount of a second solution to yield a total amount of a new solution.
subClasses.example: Dried apricots are 5% protein and dried prunes are 2% protein. How much of each type of fruit should be used to make a 100-gram mixture that is 3% protein?

subClasses.name: Simple percent
subClasses.template: A certain percentage of a total yields a part.
subClasses.example: Suppose 10% of 1200 students were absent. How many students were absent?

subClasses.name: Simple ratio
subClasses.template: A number of elements is related to another number based on some ratio.
subClasses.example: The ratio of women to men in a class is 8 to 5. If there are 40 women, how many men are there?

subClasses.name: Simple fraction
subClasses.template: A certain fraction of a total yields a part.
subClasses.example: About $2 billion is spent on advertising in magazines. Of this 4/5 is spent on TV ads. How much is spent on TV ads?

subClasses.name: Simple index
subClasses.template: A certain index of a total yields a part.
subClasses.example: A TV set with tubes uses about 640 kilowatt hours of electricity per year. This is 1.6 times that used by solid state sets. How many kilowatt hours does the solid state model use in a year?

subClasses.name: Simple proportion
subClasses.template: A certain proportion of a total yields a part.
subClasses.example: Lee's batting average is 0.675. How many hits should Lee score in 5000 times at bat?

subClasses.name: Direct - Miscellaneous
subClasses.template: If a certain amount corresponds to a certain number of units, then a different amount will correspond to a different number of units.
subClasses.example: If a machine can make 1000 bolts in 2 hours, working at the same rate how many can it make in 5 hours?

subClasses.name: Direct - Unit cost
subClasses.template: If a certain number of units cost a certain total amount, then a different number of units cost a different total amount.
subClasses.example: Twelve slices of pizza cost $6. How much would eight slices cost?

subClasses.name: Direct - Travel
subClasses.template: If a certain distance can be covered in a certain number of days (or using a certain amount of gas), then a different distance can be covered in a different number of days (or using a different amount of gas).
subClasses.example: Maria traveled 700 kilometers in 5 days. At this rate how far would she travel in 24 days?

subClasses.name: Direct - Map scale
subClasses.template: If a certain length on a map corresponds to a certain actual distance, then a different length on the map corresponds to another distance.
subClasses.example: If 5 em on a map represent 400 kilometers, what distance do 16 em represent?

subClasses.name: Inverse - Pressure volume
subClasses.template: The volume of gas under a certain pressure changes to a different volume under a different pressure.
subClasses.example: The volume of gas varies inversely with the pressure upon it. The volume of a gas is 200 cm^2 under a pressure of 32 kg/cm^2 . What will be its volume under a pressure of 40 kg/cm^2

subClasses.name: Inverse - Physics
subClasses.template: A rate that produces a certain amount is changed to a different rate that produces a different amount.
subClasses.example: The current in an electrical conductor varies inversely with the resistance of the conductor. The current is 2 amps when the resistance is 960 ohms. What is the current when the resistance is 540 ohms?

subClasses.name: Inverse - Motion
subClasses.template: If it takes a certain amount of time to travel a distance at a certain rate, how long will it take to cover the same distance at a different rate?
subClasses.example: The time to drive a certain distance varies inversely with the speed of the vehicle. Mary Bronson drives 47 mph for 4 hours. How long would it take her to make the same trip at 55 mph?

subClasses.name: Inverse - Work
subClasses.template: If it takes a certain number of workers a certain amount of time to do a job, how long would it take a different number of workers?
subClasses.example: If it takes 4 hours for 9 cooks to prepare a school lunch, how long would it take 8 cooks to prepare the lunch?

subClasses.name: Rectangle simple area
subClasses.template: The area of a rectangle can be determined by multiplying length with width.
subClasses.example: The Kroger's rectangular garden measures 12 yards by 15 yards. What is the area of their garden?

subClasses.name: Rectangle Frame absolute
subClasses.template: A frame with a certain width surrounds a rectangle.
subClasses.example: A framed mirror is 40 cm by 55 cm. 1924 cm^2 of the mirror shows. Find the width of the frame.

subClasses.name: Rectangle area relative
subClasses.template: A certain area of a rectangle occurs when the length is related to width in a certain way.
subClasses.example: The length of a rectangular window pane is twice its width. The area of the pane is 98 cm^2. What are the dimensions of the pane?

subClasses.name: Triangle Pythagoreon
subClasses.template: Given the length of two sides of a right triangle, find the length of the remaining side.
subClasses.example: A 26-foot ladder is leaning against a building. The foot of the ladder is 10 ft. away from the building. How far above the ground does the ladder touch the wall?

subClasses.name: Fulcrum - Two weights absolute
subClasses.template: One object is positioned a certain distance from a fulcrum such that it is balanced with another object that is positioned a certain distance on the other side.
subClasses.example: Laurie weighs 60 kg and is sitting 165 cm from the fulcrum of a seesaw. Bill weighs 55 kg. How far from the fulcrum must Bill sit to balance the seesaw?

subClasses.name: Parts - Two piece relative
subClasses.template: A certain object (or amount) is broken into two parts.
subClasses.example: An 8-meter rope is cut into two pieces. One piece is 3 meters longer than the other. How long are the pieces?

subClasses.name: Progression - Increment decrement
subClasses.template: A certain number is incremented by a constant and added to total, recursively.
subClasses.example: Joan saves 1 dime the 1st day, 2 dimes the 2nd day, 3 dimes the 3rd day, and so on. How much money will she have saved at the end of 30 days?

subClasses.name: Age - Relative now then
subClasses.template: Relative ages for two people now are compared to their relative ages at some other time.
subClasses.example: Ann Teak is twice as old as her son. Ten years ago Ann was three times as old as her son. What are their present ages?

subClasses.name: Age - Absolute now then
subClasses.template: Absolute ages for two people now are compared to their relative ages at some other time.
subClasses.example: A man is now 40 years old and his son is 14 years old. A number of years from now the father will be twice as old as his son. What is this number of years?
